title: 106_s2748
content: The Act is titled the "Russian-American Trust and Cooperation Act of 2000". The Congress finds that the Russian Federation operates an intelligence facility at Lourdes, Cuba, leased for $100-300 million a year, which is used for intelligence activities against the United States. The Lourdes facility in Cuba is the largest complex operated by the Russian Federation outside the former Soviet Union. It covers a 28 square-mile area with over 1,500 Russian personnel. The base has tracking dishes and a satellite system for intercepting communications. The predecessor regime of the Russian Federation obtained sensitive information about US military operations. The Lourdes facility in Cuba, operated by the Russian Federation, collects sensitive information about US military operations and engages in cyberwarfare against the United States. The facility's operational significance has increased since 1996. The Russian intelligence community has been ordered to increase gathering of US and Western economic secrets. The Russian government has spent over $3 billion on the Lourdes facility, which was visited by a high-ranking military delegation in 1999. SEC. 3. PROHIBITION ON BILATERAL DEBT RESCHEDULING AND FORGIVENESS FOR THE RUSSIAN FEDERATION. Prohibition on rescheduling or forgiving Russian Federation's bilateral debt to the US until Russia closes intelligence facility in Cuba. President can waive this with 10 days notice. The President can waive the prohibition on rescheduling or forgiving Russian Federation's debt to the US if deemed necessary for national interests, with a detailed explanation required. The President may submit written certification in classified form if deemed appropriate. Every 180 days after the certification, a report must be sent to the House and Senate committees on the extent of meeting specified requirements. SEC. 4. REPORT ON THE CLOSING OF THE INTELLIGENCE FACILITY AT LOURDES, CUBA. The President must provide a report every 120 days to specified committees on Russia's actions to close the intelligence facility in Cuba and federal agencies' efforts to verify these actions.
